TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM
 BRONCHOSCOPY - At [**2167-6-10**] 01:53 AM
   - Admitted to MICU
   - Bronch done with large amount of yellow sputum throughout left
   airways but no obstructing lesions.
   - Unable to place A-line
   - Increased PEEP, decreased FiO2, and decreased Vt overnight
   - SBP decreased to 80s (MAP 65) with normalization of lactate but
   decreased UOP 25cc/h. Given 500cc bolus x 2 and propofol decreased with
   improvement in SBP to 90s and MAP >65 but no change in UOP.
   --
   Collateral info: Per b/f, PCP is [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]. Pt with h/o bipolar
   disorder and had been very awake for 4-5 days. On Monday, b/f unable to
   arouse her from sleep. Still sleeping when returned from work. Tuesday
   AM, still unable to wake her. Noted urinary incontinence so called EMS.
   No observed tonic clonic movements or bowel incontinence; no h/o
   seizure d/o. Concern for overdose given empty pill bottles found near
   her. Per b/f, pt overdosed 8-9 years ago. Did not convey recent SI but
   multiple stressors recently including ongoing psych med adjustments,
   CCY several weeks ago, and arguments with parents and b/f. No fevers,
   change in chronic cough, or SOB per b/f. PMH notable for bipolar
   disorder, thyroid disorder (unclear if taking meds), and EtOH
   neuropathy. SH notable for 1.5 ppd x 25 years, h/o EtOH abuse but none
   in [**5-11**] years. H/o cocaine 10 years ago; no h/o IVDU. ROS notable for
   some leg edema s/p CCY. NKDA. FH: Mother with CHF. SH: Lives with
   long-time boyfriend; was phlebotomist in past.
   Allergies:
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - [**2167-6-10**] 02:02 AM
   Levofloxacin - [**2167-6-10**] 04:00 AM
   Infusions:

[**2167-6-10**] 1:08 am SPUTUM      Source: Endotracheal.
   GRAM STAIN (Final [**2167-6-10**]):
      >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.
      3+  (5-10 per 1000X FIELD):   MULTIPLE ORGANISMS CONSISTENT WITH
                                    OROPHARYNGEAL FLORA.
   RESPIRATORY CULTURE (Preliminary):
   [**2167-6-10**] Urine legionella Ag pending
   [**2167-6-9**] Bcx NGTD x 2
   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o unclear psych history and reported hypothyroidism
   who presented to OSH with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory
   failure requiring intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left
   lung atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Likely CAP v. aspiration although unknown whether pt with risk factors
   for HAP.  Favor broad antibiotic coverage at this time pending further
   micro and clinical history data.
   - Vancomycin, zosyn for empiric coverage of HAP and aspiration pna;
   Levofloxacin for empiric coverage
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures, urine legionella
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily RSBI/SBT
   - Wean sedation as tolerated
   - Not ARDS as unilateral but given P/F <200, absence of CHF will aim
   for Vt 4-6 mg/kg, uptitrate PEEP prn with caution given unilateral
   - Obtain medical history from PCP
   .
   # Hypotension: Concern for sepsis in setting of pneumonia. U/A u
   # Elevated lactate: Anion gap 13. Likely elevated lactate in setting of
   hypoperfusion. [**Month (only) 11**] have had decreased po intake recently in setting of
   acute illness although also concern for sepsis given above findings.
   Currently maintaing MAP >60.
   - Trend lactate
   - IV fluid hydration
   - Goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   - Abx as above
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Moderate sized on CT chest. No pulsus
   paradoxicus on exam (8).
   - TTE in AM to evaluate
   .
   # ?Hypothyroidism: Per OSH report, unclear history and no levothyroxine
   in med bag
   - Check TSH
   - Clarify with PCP in AM
   .
   # Increased lethargy: Presenting complaint to OSH. Unclear psych
   history. Also question of seizure disorder given the meds with her.
   - Reassess neuro status as wean sedation
   - Hold topiramate and divalproex for now; seizure precautions
   - Hold seroquel, clonazepam, and provigil for now
   - Clarify with PCP in AM
   .
   # Insomnia: On zolpidem prn as outpatient. Holding for now.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: OGT awaiting placement confirmation, nutrition c/s for tube
   feeds
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2167-6-9**] 11:59 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ heparin, pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: H2B
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Boyfriend [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 7171**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7172**] H,
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7173**]. Father [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 1247**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7174**] (currently fighting;
   mother in hospital). Sister [**Name (NI) 1298**] in [**Name (NI) 122**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7175**] H, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7176**]
   C. Also has 4 stepbrothers.. Psychiatrist [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) 3743**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 7166**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7167**].
   Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] from [**Hospital1 49**] ([**Hospital 7177**] Clinic).
   Code status: Presumed full
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the MICU with respiratory failure, hypoxemic, and intubated. She has a history of unclear psychiatric issues, hypothyroidism, and ethanol abuse. The patient's recent events include:

* Invasive ventilation started at 12:00 AM
* Bronchoscopy done at 1:53 AM, which revealed yellow sputum in the left airway but no obstructing lesions
* Unable to place an arterial line (A-line)
* Increased PEEP, decreased FiO2, and decreased Vt overnight
* SBP decreased to 80s (MAP 65) with normalization of lactate but decreased UOP (25cc/h)
* Given 500cc bolus x 2 and propofol decreased with improvement in SBP to 90s and MAP >65 but no change in UOP

The patient's medical history includes:

* Bipolar disorder
* Thyroid disorder (unclear if taking medication)
* EtOH neuropathy
* H/o cocaine use 10 years ago
* H/o EtOH abuse but none in the past 5-11 years
* Mother with CHF

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 11.3 K/uL
* Hct: 31.7%
* Plt: 214 K/uL
* Cr: 0.7 mg/dL
* TCO2: 26
* Glucose: 122 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 14.3/28.6/1.2, Lactic Acid: 1.1 mmol/L, Ca++: 7.8 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest imaging: Left lung collapse/atelectasis

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: Left lung collapse/atelectasis likely secondary to mucous plugging from extensive consolidative pneumonia. Broad antibiotic coverage is recommended pending further micro and clinical history data.
* Hypotension: Concern for sepsis in the setting of pneumonia. U/A u, elevated lactate, and decreased UOP.
* Elevated lactate: Anion gap 13. Likely elevated lactate in the setting of hypoperfusion.
* Pericardial effusion: Moderate-sized on CT chest. No pulsus paradoxus on exam.
*?Hypothyroidism: Per OSH report, unclear history and no levothyroxine in med bag.
* Increased lethargy: Presenting complaint to OSH. Unclear psychiatric history. Also question of seizure disorder given the medications with her.
* Insomnia: On zolpidem prn as outpatient. Holding for now.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis due to pneumonia
* Hypothyroidism
* Seizure disorder
* Respiratory failure
* Hypotension
* Pericardial effusion
* Insomnia

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and radiology reports to adjust the treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the MICU with respiratory failure, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. She has a history of bipolar disorder, thyroid disorder, and EtOH neuropathy. She presented to the emergency department with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure, and was found to have left lung collapse on chest imaging.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 360 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.46, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 37 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 149 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's blood pressure is 87/59 mmHg, and her heart rate is 80 beats per minute. Her cardiac rhythm is normal sinus rhythm.
* Neurological status: The patient is sedated and intubated, and her neurological status is unclear due to the sedation.
* Renal status: The patient's urine output is 25 mL per hour, and her creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL.
* Hepatic status: The patient's liver function tests are not mentioned in the note.
* Endocrine status: The patient's thyroid function is unclear, and she is not receiving thyroid medication.

The patient's medical history includes:

* Bipolar disorder
* Thyroid disorder (unclear if she is taking medication)
* EtOH neuropathy
* H/o cocaine use 10 years ago
* H/o EtOH abuse, but none in the past 5-11 years

The patient's family history is notable for:

* Mother with chronic heart failure

The patient's social history is notable for:

* Lives with her long-time boyfriend
* Was a phlebotomist in the past

The patient's allergies are not mentioned in the note.

The patient's medications include:

* Propofol
* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Levofloxacin
* Vancomycin
* H2 blocker for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* SQ heparin for DVT prophylaxis
* Pneumoboots for DVT prophylaxis

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to her pneumonia and the presence of multiple organisms in her sputum sample.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require further interventions to improve her oxygenation and ventilation.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, hypoxemic, and requiring intubation. She has a history of bipolar disorder, thyroid disorder, and EtOH neuropathy. She presented to the emergency department with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure, and was found to have left lung collapse on chest imaging. She was given empiric antibiotic coverage for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation, PEEP 10 cmH2O, FiO2 60%, Vt 360 mL
* Hemodynamic monitoring: MAP >65, SBP 90s
* Fluid balance: IV fluid hydration, goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
* Sedation: Propofol, weaning as tolerated
* Antibiotics: Vancomycin, Zosyn, Levofloxacin
* Laboratory results: WBC 11.3 K/uL, Hct 31.7%, Plt 214 K/uL, Cr 0.7 mg/dL, TCO2 26 mmol/L
* Sputum culture: Gram stain shows multiple organisms consistent with oropharyngeal flora
* Respiratory culture: Legionella Ag pending
* Urine culture: Legionella Ag pending

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's pneumonia and hypotension, there is a high risk of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's unclear history of hypothyroidism may be contributing to her lethargy and other symptoms.
4. Seizure disorder: The patient's history of seizure disorder and the medications she is taking may increase her risk of seizures.
5. Insomnia: The patient's insomnia may worsen if not properly managed.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may spread to other areas of her lungs, leading to further complications.
7. Hypoxemia: The patient's hypoxemia may worsen if not properly managed.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's moderate-sized pericardial effusion may lead to cardiac complications if not properly managed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage her sepsis with IV fluid hydration and antibiotics.
3. Reassess her neuro status as wean sedation and consider holding her seizure medications.
4. Clarify her history of hypothyroidism and consider checking her TSH level.
5. Continue to monitor her urine output and adjust her fluid management as needed.
6. Consider obtaining a TTE to evaluate her pericardial effusion.
7. Consider adjusting her antibiotic coverage based on the results of her sputum and blood cultures.
8. Continue to monitor her for signs of cardiac complications and adjust her management as needed.

   43 yo female with h/o unclear psych history and reported hypothyroidism
   who presented to OSH with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory
   failure requiring intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left
   lung atelectasis/collapse given mediastinal shift with concern for
   bronchial obstruction. Leukocytosis and copious secretions suggestive
   of pneumonia complicated by mucus plugging causing lung collapse.
   Differential for consolidative appearance on CT include staph
   (?post-influenza), strep, legionella, klebsiella (red-colored sputum
   suctioned). In light of presenting sx of lethargy, aspiration event in
   possible with concern for anaerobes; baseline status unknown and unable
   to assess currently d/t sedation. Lastly, may have underlying tracheal
   obstruction and subsequent post-obstructive pneumonia; past medical
   history unknown. Given rapid clinical decline and striking CT findings,
   would favor broad antibiotic coverage pending further work-up. Necrotic
   appearing sputum suggests subacute process.
   - Vancomycin, zosyn for empiric coverage of HAP and aspiration pna;
   Levofloxacin for empiric coverage
   - Check sputum and blood cultures, urine legionella
   - Npo with plan for bronch
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily RSBI/SBT
   - Wean sedation as tolerated
   - Not ARDS as unilateral but given P/F <200, absence of CHF will aim

   - Obtain medical history from PCP

   hypoperfusion. [**Month (only) 11**] have had decreased po intake recently in setting of
   acute illness although also concern for sepsis given above findings.
   Currently maintaing MAP >60.

   - Goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h

   paradoxicus on exam (8).
   - TTE in AM to evaluate
   .
   # ?Hypothyroidism: Per OSH report, unclear history and no levothyroxine
   in med bag
   - Check TSH
   - Clarify with PCP in AM
   .
   # Increased lethargy: Presenting complaint to OSH. Unclear psych
   history. Also question of seizure disorder given the meds with her.
   - Reassess neuro status as wean sedation
   - Hold topiramate and divalproex for now; seizure precautions
   - Hold seroquel, clonazepam, and provigil for now
   - Clarify with PCP in AM

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure and left lung collapse. She was intubated and placed on invasive ventilation. The patient has a history of unclear psychiatric history and reported hypothyroidism. Her presentation included increased lethargy, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and leukocytosis. Imaging studies showed a left lung white-out on chest imaging consistent with left lung atelectasis/collapse. The patient has a high suspicion of pneumonia complicated by mucus plugging causing lung collapse, and a differential diagnosis includes staph, strep, legionella, and klebsiella. The patient was started on broad antibiotic coverage with vancomycin, zosyn, and levofloxacin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has a high suspicion of pneumonia, which can lead to further respiratory failure, sepsis, and organ dysfunction.
2. Mucus plugging: The patient's lung collapse may be caused by mucus plugging, which can lead to further respiratory failure and difficulty weaning from the ventilator.
3. Aspiration: The patient's lethargy and sedation may increase the risk of aspiration, which can lead to pneumonia and other complications.
4. Tracheal obstruction: The patient's past medical history is unknown, and there is a concern for tracheal obstruction, which can lead to post-obstructive pneumonia and other complications.
5. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated lactate suggest sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
6. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a moderate-sized pericardial effusion, which can lead to cardiac tamponade and cardiac arrest if not treated promptly.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's reported hypothyroidism may need to be further evaluated and treated to prevent complications such as myxedema coma.
8. Seizure disorder: The patient's medications and unclear psychiatric history suggest a possible seizure disorder, which needs to be further evaluated and treated to prevent seizures and other complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad antibiotic coverage with vancomycin, zosyn, and levofloxacin.
2. Wean the patient from sedation and assess her neuro status.
3. Evaluate the patient's pericardial effusion with a TTE and consider pericardiocentesis if necessary.
4. Clarify the patient's psychiatric history and consider consulting a psychiatrist.
5. Evaluate the patient's hypothyroidism with a TSH and consider starting levothyroxine therapy.
6. Consider holding the patient's seizure medications and starting anticonvulsant therapy if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's lactate levels and consider adjusting her fluid management and antibiotic therapy as necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilation settings as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old woman with a significant psychiatric history, including a prior history of drug overdose, who was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. She is currently on mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 60% and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 87/59 mmHg. She has a pericardial effusion noted on CT scan and obtundation attributed to polypharmacy and a history of overdose.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and weaning from mechanical ventilation may be challenging. Pneumonia or aspiration may be contributing to her hypoxemic respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and hypotension overnight suggest possible sepsis. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started, and further evaluation is needed to determine the source of sepsis.
3. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may be causing cardiac compromise, and an echocardiogram is planned to further evaluate this.
4. Obtundation: The patient's obtundation may be related to polypharmacy, including sedatives, and a history of overdose. Further evaluation of her psychiatric regimen and compliance is needed.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is receiving tube feeds, but it is unclear when they will be started. Malnutrition may be a concern, especially given her critical illness.
6. Glycemic control: The patient's blood sugar is well-controlled, but hyperglycemia may still be a concern, especially in critically ill patients.
7. Venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis: The patient is receiving SQ UF Heparin for DVT prophylaxis, but further evaluation is needed to determine the effectiveness of this therapy.
8. Stress ulcer prophylaxis: The patient is receiving an H2 blocker for stress ulcer prophylaxis, but further evaluation is needed to determine the effectiveness of this therapy.
9. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prophylaxis: The patient is receiving HOB elevation, mouth care, and daily wake-up to reduce the risk of VAP. Further evaluation is needed to determine the effectiveness of this therapy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old woman with a history of psychiatric issues, including a prior drug overdose, and is currently intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure.

The patient's 24-hour events include a bronchoscopy without airway obstruction, but with thick yellow sputum aspirated. She received 2.5L of IV fluids overnight for marginal urine output and hypotension, which was fluid responsive.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure of 87/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Her hemodynamic monitoring shows a fluid balance of 2,161 mL, with 245 mL of urine output and 1,185 mL of blood products transfused.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.9 g/dL, platelet count of 214 K/uL, and creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL. Her imaging studies reveal a left lower lobe collapse with lingular and left upper lobe infiltrate, pericardial effusion, and a patulous esophagus.

The patient's assessment and plan include hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely caused by community-acquired pneumonia, hospital-acquired pneumonia, or aspiration with mucous plugging. The plan is to wean the patient off sedation and perform a pressure support ventilation trial, while continuing broad antibiotic coverage with vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin.

The patient also has possible sepsis, with hypotension and elevated lactate levels, and will be closely monitored for signs of instability. If unstable, a central venous catheter and arterial line may be placed.

The patient's pericardial effusion will be further evaluated with an echocardiogram today. Her obtundation is likely related to polypharmacy and a history of overdose, and will be further evaluated with a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) test and clarification of her psychiatric regimen.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to respiratory arrest or chronic lung disease.
2. Sepsis: The patient's possible sepsis may progress to severe sepsis or septic shock if not promptly treated, leading to multi-organ failure and increased mortality.
3. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiac tamponade or cardiac arrest.
4. Sedation-related complications: The patient's polypharmacy and history of overdose may increase the risk of sedation-related complications, such as respiratory depression or cardiac arrest.
5. Infection-related complications: The patient's polymicrobial infection may lead to complications such as sepsis, abscess formation, or bacteremia.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's inability to eat or drink may lead to nutritional deficiencies, such as malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's patulous esophagus may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as aspiration, vomiting, or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch, 59.1 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of bipolar disorder and respiratory failure. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a pressure support of 5 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 50%. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, and blood pressure of 95/65 mmHg. The patient's peripheral vascular examination is not assessed due to intubation. The patient's neurologic examination is also not assessed due to sedation.

The patient's lab results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.9 g/dL, and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 214 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.9 mEq/L.

The patient's respiratory support is set to CPAP/PSV with a tidal volume of 360 mL and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on an FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's medical history includes a small pericardial effusion without tamponade, and hypotension not meeting the criteria for shock.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and lack of prophylactic measures.
3. Stress ulcer due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and sedation.
4. Hypoglycemia due to inadequate glycemic control.
5. Cardiac tamponade or worsening pericardial effusion due to inadequate management.
6. Respiratory failure due to inadequate ventilation or underlying lung disease.
7. Sepsis or septic shock due to underlying infections or inadequate antimicrobial therapy.
8. Neurologic complications due to prolonged sedation and intubation.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of unclear psychiatric history and reported hypothyroidism, who presented to the emergency department with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation and found to have left lung collapse.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging consistent with left lung atelectasis/collapse, likely secondary to mucous plugging from extensive consolidative pneumonia.
* Pericardial effusion: Moderate-sized on CT chest, without tamponade.
* Hypotension: Borderline, not in shock.
* Lactic acidosis: Elevated anion gap, likely due to hypoperfusion.
* Sedation: Currently receiving propofol, which may be contributing to the patient's altered mental status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's pneumonia and elevated lactate levels, there is a risk of developing sepsis.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP.
3. Pericardial tamponade: Although the patient's pericardial effusion is not causing tamponade currently, there is a risk of it developing in the future.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's reported history of hypothyroidism is unclear, and it is essential to confirm this diagnosis and adjust treatment accordingly.
5. Medication withdrawal syndrome: The patient is receiving multiple medications, including benzodiazepines and anticonvulsants, which may lead to withdrawal symptoms if discontinued abruptly.
6. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may be due to sedation, but it is also possible that she is experiencing delirium, which can be a complication of critical illness.

To address these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored, and the following interventions should be considered:

1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover HAP and aspiration pneumonia.
2. Further evaluation of the patient's psychiatric history and potential medication withdrawal syndrome.
3. Titration of sedation to minimize the risk of delirium.
4. Monitoring of the patient's lactate levels and adjusting fluid management accordingly.
5. Evaluation of the patient's thyroid function and potential treatment of hypothyroidism.
6. Consideration of switching to alternative sedation medications, such as fentanyl and versed, if the patient's hypotension persists.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, requiring intubation, and found to have left lung collapse. She has a history of unclear psychiatric issues, reported hypothyroidism, and is taking medications for bipolar disorder. The patient's condition has been stable overnight, with improved oxygenation and reduced respiratory support. However, she remains intubated and sedated.

The patient's labs show an elevated anion gap and lactate level, which may be related to her underlying medical conditions or medication use. Her thyroid function tests show a markedly elevated TSH level, indicating hypothyroidism. The patient's mental status is altered, and she is currently receiving medications for her bipolar disorder.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's infection, likely pneumonia, may progress to sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to her prolonged intubation and respiratory support.
3. Hypotension: The patient's baseline blood pressure is unknown, and she may be at risk for hypotension due to her infection, sedation, and potential sepsis.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade, which may be a sign of underlying cardiac disease or infection.
5. Thyroid disorder: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her altered mental status and other symptoms.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count may be a sign of infection or inflammation.
7. Anion gap: The patient's elevated anion gap may indicate a metabolic acidosis or other underlying metabolic disorder.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat the patient's pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and wean ventilator support as tolerated.
3. Reassess the patient's mental status and adjust sedation as needed.
4. Check thyroid function tests and consider treating the patient's hypothyroidism.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluids and medications as needed.
6. Consider switching to fentanyl and versed if the patient's hypotension persists.
7. Recheck the patient's urine analysis and consider checking for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

The patient, a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and presenting with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure, remains intubated and sedated in the ICU. The patient's condition has improved slightly, with a decrease in the size of the left upper lobe consolidation and a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C (97.7°F), heart rate of 92 beats per minute, blood pressure of 95/65 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.3 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 31.7%
* Platelet count: 214 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Total CO2: 26 mmHg
* Glucose: 122 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest radiograph: Marked improvement in the aeration of the left upper lobe, with a small left pleural effusion and dense left lower lobe consolidation.
* Transthoracic echocardiogram: Normal-sized left atrium, normal systolic function, and mild mitral regurgitation.

The patient's medical conditions and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: Left lung collapse likely secondary to mucous plugging from extensive consolidative pneumonia. The patient is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocyte count is increasing, and the differential is pending.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is stable, but the patient may have sepsis contributing to hypotension.
* Anion gap: The patient's anion gap is elevated at 15, and lactate levels are being monitored.
* Pericardial effusion: The patient has a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade.
* Thyroid disorder: The patient may have hypothyroidism, and TSH levels are elevated. Levothyroxine is being considered.
* Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement since admission and is being treated with a bowel regimen.
* Increased lethargy/altered mental status: The patient's mental status is likely related to hypothyroidism, medication effect, and known bipolar disorder.

The patient's medications include:

* Propofol for sedation
* Vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and levofloxacin for broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage
* Famotidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin for DVT prophylaxis
* Fentanyl and versed for pain management

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Weaning of sedation and mechanical ventilation as tolerated
* Reassessing neuro status and restarting home medications as appropriate
* Holding certain medications, such as seroquel and clonazepam, pending further evaluation.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Pneumonia and respiratory failure
* Hypothyroidism and myxedema coma
* Constipation and bowel obstruction
* Leukocytosis and neutropenia
* Hypotension and cardiac arrest
* Anion gap and metabolic acidosis
* Pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to prevent these complications and ensure the patient's optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, left lung collapse, and unclear psychiatric history. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder, reportedly poorly controlled, and may have hypothyroidism. She was intubated and sedated upon admission.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T: 36.5°C (97.7°F), HR: 92 bpm, BP: 95/65 mmHg, RR: 12 inspirations per minute, SpO2: 100%
* Respiratory support: Endotracheal tube, CPAP/PSV mode, Vt: 360 mL, PS: 5 cmH2O, PEEP: 5 cmH2O, FiO2: 50%
* Laboratory results: WBC: 11.3, Hct: 31.7, Plt: 214, Cr: 0.7, TCO2: 26, Glucose: 122 mg/dL, Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L, Albumin: 3.2 g/dL, Ca++: 7.8 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 2.6 mg/dL, TSH: 54
* Imaging studies: CXR shows marked improvement in the aeration of the left upper lobe, dense left lower lobe consolidation, and a small pericardial effusion. TTE shows normal left atrium, no atrial septal defect, estimated right atrial pressure of 0-10 mmHg, normal left ventricular wall thickness and systolic function, and trace aortic regurgitation and mild mitral regurgitation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further lung collapse and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
* Pneumonia: The patient's diagnosis of pneumonia may lead to further complications such as sepsis, respiratory failure, and potentially life-threatening infections.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's reported hypothyroidism may lead to further complications such as myxedema coma, hypothermia, and bradycardia if not properly managed.
* Anion gap: The patient's elevated anion gap may indicate a metabolic disorder, which may lead to further complications such as acidosis, electrolyte imbalances, and potentially life-threatening conditions.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's increased leukocytosis may indicate an inflammatory response, which may lead to further complications such as sepsis, respiratory failure, and potentially life-threatening infections.
* Pericardial effusion: The patient's small pericardial effusion may lead to further complications such as cardiac tamponade, which may require emergency surgical intervention.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as sepsis, respiratory failure, and potentially life-threatening conditions.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is recommended to:

* Continue respiratory support with CPAP/PSV mode and wean sedation as tolerated.
* Continue broad antibiotic coverage for pneumonia and monitor for signs of sepsis.
* Monitor for signs of hypothyroidism and consider thyroid function tests.
* Monitor for signs of anion gap and electrolyte imbalances and consider further laboratory testing.
* Monitor for signs of leukocytosis and consider further laboratory testing.
* Monitor for signs of pericardial effusion and consider further imaging studies.
* Monitor for signs of hypotension and consider further management strategies.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely caused by community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), or aspiration with mucous plugging. The patient is currently on positive pressure ventilation (PSV) and has been stabilized. However, the patient's mental status remains somewhat precluding extubation.

The patient has a history of polypharmacy, including mood stabilizers, which may contribute to their obtundation. A recent CT scan revealed a pericardial effusion, but there is no evidence of tamponade. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and creatinine levels, indicating possible sepsis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 91 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 100% on CPAP/PSV. The patient's urine output is reasonable, and they are receiving fluid resuscitation targeted to their urine output and blood pressure.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if their underlying infection is not adequately treated or if they develop further complications such as pneumonia or aspiration.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and white blood cell count suggest possible sepsis, which could worsen their condition if not managed promptly and effectively.
3. Pericardial tamponade: Although the CT scan did not show evidence of tamponade, the patient's pericardial effusion could still progress and cause cardiac compromise.
4. Thyroid-related complications: The patient's profound hypothyroidism may lead to further complications, such as myxedema, if not managed properly.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of polypharmacy and the use of anticoagulants may increase their risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest possible renal failure, which could worsen their condition if not managed promptly and effectively.
7. Infection-related complications: The patient's underlying infection could lead to further complications, such as abscesses, empyemas, or septic shock, if not adequately treated.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address their complex medical condition and prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall, 59.1 kg individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to left lower lobe (LLL) pneumonia. The patient has been receiving antibiotics, including piperacillin/tazobactam, levofloxacin, and vancomycin, as well as other medications such as heparin, famotidine, and mood stabilizers.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.5°F, heart rate of 91 bpm, blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on 40% FiO2, and they are receiving continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with a pressure support ventilation (PSV) mode.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, with normal breath sounds, soft abdomen, and absent peripheral pulses. The patient is sedated and unable to respond to verbal commands.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a platelet count of 222 K/uL. The patient's lactate level is 1.1 mmol/L, and their blood glucose level is 122 mg/dL. Other laboratory results include an elevated troponin level, indicating possible cardiac injury.

The patient has a pericardial effusion, as noted on a computed tomography (CT) scan, but no evidence of tamponade. They also have obtundation, which may be related to polypharmacy, profound hypothyroidism, and possible myxedema.

The patient's plan includes continuing broad antibiotic coverage, narrowing in another 24 hours based on CX data, and following up with blood and bronchial samples for culture. They will also receive IV levothyroxine and have their mood stabilizers held.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and hypotension suggest possible sepsis, which may progress to organ dysfunction or failure if not treated promptly.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin level and pericardial effusion may indicate cardiac injury or failure, which could worsen if not managed appropriately.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's obtundation may be related to polypharmacy, hypothyroidism, or myxedema, and may worsen if not managed promptly.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's tube feeds have been held, which may lead to malnutrition and worsen their respiratory failure.
6. Infection: The patient's LLL pneumonia may worsen or spread to other areas of the lung, leading to further respiratory compromise.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia may indicate cardiovascular instability, which could worsen if not managed promptly.

   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Sputum cx now growing S. aureus sensitive to oxacillin. Partial
   re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent left mid-lung infiltrate.
   Increase in leukocytosis but no recent fevers.
   - continue zosyn
   - D/c levofloxacin and vancomycin
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily wake-up and SBT
   - will re bronch today to assess airway
   Leukocytosis: Pt remains afebrile; unclear why WBC cont to rise with
   variable left-shift. Currently treating pneumonia. Repeat U/A
   unremarkable; Ucx pending. Not on steroids. Ddx includes seizure.  Also
   of concern would be complicated pneumonia versus parapneumonia
   effusion.
   - Cont to trend WBC and temp curve
   - Abx as above pending sputum, blood, and urine cx data
   - Consider EEG
   Altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH with limited
   response off sedation. CT head negative. Likely hypothyroidism
   contributing with possibility of myxedema coma; h/o poor control. Given
   positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone, concern for
   overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related to known bipolar
   disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known seizure disorder.
   - Appreciate endo recs; given loading dose of levothyroxine 300mcg and
   to cont on 75mcg daily
   - Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel, clonazepam, and
   zolpidem for now
   - Consider EEG
   - Reassess neuro status daily off propofol
   Hypothyroidism: Poorly controlled with widely fluctuating TSH on review
   of past med records.
   - Cont levothyroxine 75mcg
   - F/u cortisol level to assess adrenal axis
   - F/u endo recs
   Bipolar disorder: Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel
   and clonazepam for now
   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of
   infection but MAPs stably above goal off pressors with likely
   contribution from used for sedation.
   - consider switching to fentanyl/versed if persistent hypotension
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Improved to 13 today. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
   and benzos. [**Month (only) 11**] have ketosis from poor po intake.

   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.

   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Sputum cx now growing S. aureus sensitive to oxacillin. Partial
   re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent left mid-lung infiltrate.
   Increase in leukocytosis but no recent fevers.
   - continue zosyn
   - D/c levofloxacin and vancomycin
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily wake-up and SBT
   - will re bronch today to assess airway
   Leukocytosis: Pt remains afebrile; unclear why WBC cont to rise with
   variable left-shift. Currently treating pneumonia. Repeat U/A
   unremarkable; Ucx pending. Not on steroids. Ddx includes seizure.  Also
   of concern would be complicated pneumonia versus parapneumonia
   effusion.
   - Cont to trend WBC and temp curve
   - Abx as above pending sputum, blood, and urine cx data
   - Consider EEG
   Altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH with limited
   response off sedation. CT head negative. Likely hypothyroidism
   contributing with possibility of myxedema coma; h/o poor control. Given
   positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone, concern for
   overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related to known bipolar
   disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known seizure disorder.
   - Appreciate endo recs; given loading dose of levothyroxine 300mcg and
   to cont on 75mcg daily
   - Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel, clonazepam, and
   zolpidem for now
   - Consider EEG

   - F/u endo recs

   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of

   contribution from used for sedation.

   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and poorly controlled thyroid levels. She was admitted to the ICU with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure, requiring intubation. The patient has been diagnosed with left lung collapse and consolidative pneumonia, with S. aureus growing in her sputum culture. She is being treated with antibiotics and has been given a loading dose of levothyroxine for hypothyroidism.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's infection can lead to sepsis, which can cause multi-organ failure.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia can worsen, leading to respiratory failure, and potentially require mechanical ventilation.
3. Myxedema coma: The patient's hypothyroidism can lead to myxedema coma, which can cause altered mental status, coma, and even death.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal axis needs to be assessed, and she may require cortisol replacement therapy.
5. Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement since admission and may require increased bowel regimen.
6. Hypotension: The patient's baseline blood pressure is unknown, and she may require vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.
7. Anion gap: The patient's anion gap is elevated, which may indicate a metabolic disorder.
8. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a small pericardial effusion, which may require further evaluation and management.
9. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to her prolonged intubation.
10. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status and prolonged sedation may increase her risk for delirium.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued antibiotic therapy for pneumonia.
2. Monitoring of her thyroid levels and potential replacement therapy.
3. Assessment of her adrenal axis and potential replacement therapy.
4. Management of her constipation.
5. Monitoring of her blood pressure and potential vasopressor therapy.
6. Evaluation and management of her pericardial effusion.
7. Monitoring for VAP and potential treatment.
8. Daily wake-up and spontaneous breathing trials to wean her from the ventilator.
9. EEG to evaluate her altered mental status.
10. Further evaluation and management of her anion gap and potential metabolic disorder.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and poorly controlled thyroid function. She was admitted to the ICU with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is still intubated and requires ventilator support. She has a moderate growth of Staphylococcus aureus in her sputum culture, which is likely contributing to her respiratory failure.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's blood pressure is stable, but she has a mildly elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate an underlying infection.
* Neurological status: The patient remains lethargic and has a decreased level of consciousness, which may be related to her hypothyroidism or potential overdose.
* Endocrine status: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and was found to have a TSH level of 54, which is elevated. She was given a loading dose of levothyroxine and is being continued on 75 mcg daily.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to the growth of Staphylococcus aureus in her sputum culture.
* Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and growth of Staphylococcus aureus in her sputum culture may indicate an underlying infection.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen if her thyroid function is not properly managed.
* Overdose: The patient's altered mental status may be related to an overdose, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
* Seizure: The patient's altered mental status and history of bipolar disorder may increase her risk of seizure.

Recommendations for further management include:

* Continue antibiotics for the patient's pneumonia and monitor for signs of infection.
* Continue thyroid replacement therapy and monitor the patient's thyroid function.
* Consider EEG to evaluate the patient's altered mental status.
* Reassess the patient's neurological status daily off propofol.
* Consider switching to fentanyl/versed if the patient's hypotension persists.
* Continue maintenance fluids and tube feeds.
* Increase bowel regimen to manage constipation.
* Monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and consider drainage if necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall, 59.1 kg female who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status, respiratory failure, and a history of thyroid abuse. The patient was weaned off sedation, but remains unresponsive to stimuli other than noxious stimuli.

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* Elevated white blood cell count (23.5 K/uL) with no bands
* Moderate Staph aureus growth in sputum culture
* Thyroid function tests reveal TSH of 54 and Free T4 <0.10
* Adrenal axis is being evaluated with an AM cortisol check

The patient is receiving IV levothyroxine and 75 mcg daily, and is being treated as if in frank myxedema coma.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 100% on CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 40%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable blood pressure and heart rate.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's unresponsiveness, but the peripheral vascular, skin, and neurologic examinations are not assessed.

The patient's laboratory results also indicate:

* Leukocytosis (23.5 K/uL)
* Hypothyroidism
* Psychiatric disease
* Respiratory failure
* Pericardial effusion
* Hypotension

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: unknown
* Glycemic control: unknown
* Lines: 18-gauge and 20-gauge IV lines
* Prophylaxis: DVT boots, SQ UF heparin; stress ulcer prophylaxis with H2 blocker; VAP prophylaxis with HOB elevation, mouth care, and daily wake-up; RSBI

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis due to the elevated white blood cell count and Staph aureus growth in the sputum culture
* Thyroid storm due to the patient's history of thyroid abuse and hypothyroidism
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying respiratory disease and potential for aspiration
* Cardiac complications due to the patient's pericardial effusion and potential for cardiac tamponade
* Adrenal insufficiency due to the patient's hypothyroidism and potential for adrenal axis dysfunction.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall, 59.1 kg female who was admitted to the ICU with a history of abusing thyroid medication for weight loss and stopping abruptly. The patient has been intubated and sedated, but has not been extubated due to lack of responsiveness to noxious stimuli.

The patient has been diagnosed with hypothyroidism, leukocytosis, and pericardial effusion without tamponade. She has also been diagnosed with respiratory failure, acute, and hypotension, but not shock.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated WBC count, elevated TSH, and decreased Free T4 levels. Her creatinine and potassium levels are within normal limits. Her albumin level is 3.2 g/dL, and her calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bronchial breath sounds bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi, and regular heart rate and rhythm. Her abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended, with present bowel sounds.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
2. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may lead to decreased metabolic rate, decreased cardiac output, and increased risk of infection.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection, which may worsen if not properly treated.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiac tamponade and cardiac arrest.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to decreased cardiac output, decreased perfusion, and increased risk of organ failure.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism with IV levothyroxine and monitor TSH and Free T4 levels regularly.
3. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and treat any underlying infections promptly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and adjust treatment as needed to prevent cardiac tamponade.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with IV fluids and vasopressors as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust treatment as needed to prevent cardiac complications.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as needed to prevent electrolyte imbalances.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust treatment as needed to prevent malnutrition.

                                    OROPHARYNGEAL FLORA.
   RESPIRATORY CULTURE (Preliminary):
      SPARSE GROWTH OROPHARYNGEAL FLORA.
      STAPH AUREUS COAG +.    MODERATE GROWTH.
   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Likely CAP v. aspiration; less likely HAP.  Urine legionella Ag neg.
   Favor broad antibiotic coverage at this time pending further micro and
   clinical history data.  Partial re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent
   left mid-lung infiltrate. Increase in leukocytosis.
   - Cont vanc, zosyn, levofloxacin for broad empiric coverage
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily RSBI/SBT
   - Wean sedation as tolerated
   Leukocytosis: Increased today. Currently treating pneumonia with broad
   abx. U/A on admit inconclusive for infection. Not on steroids.
   - Add differential
   - Recheck U/A with Ucx; check C. diff
   - Cont above abx
   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of
   infection; may have contribution from propofol used for sedation. Did
   not require pressors. Currently stable on maintenance fluids with
   improved UOP.
   - consider switching to fentanyl/versed if persistent hypotension
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Elevated at 15. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
   and benzos. [**Month (only) 11**] have ketosis from poor po intake.
   - Check lactate with next ABG
   - Recheck U/A
   - Cont maintenance fluids and tube feeds
   Pericardial effusion: Small without evidence of tamponade on TTE.
   Thyroid disorder: Per OSH report, may have hypothyroidism; rx for
   armourthyroid last filled in [**12-12**]. Unclear if pt taking medications for
   this. TSH markedly elevated.
   - Check free T4
   - start levothyroxine IV
   Constipation: No BM since admit
   - increase bowel regimen
   Increased lethargy/altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH.
   Given positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone also
   concerning for overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related
   to known bipolar disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known
   seizure disorder.
   - likely hypothyroidism contributing
   - Reassess neuro status as wean sedation
   - Restarted on home topiramate, divalproex,
   - Hold seroquel for now
   - Holding home clonazepam while on sedation
   - Holding home zolpidem

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and has been abusing thyroid medication for weight loss.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 607 mL, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 40%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's heart rate is 96 beats per minute, blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg, and cardiac rhythm is sinus rhythm.
* Neurological status: The patient is not responsive to verbal stimuli, but responds to noxious stimuli.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's central venous pressure is not elevated, and the patient is not requiring pressors.
* Renal status: The patient's urine output is 30 cc/hour, and the patient's creatinine is 0.7 mg/dL.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 23.5 K/uL, hemoglobin is 10.0 g/dL, and platelet count is 73 K/uL.
* Sputum culture: The patient's sputum culture grew moderate Staphylococcus aureus.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
* Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and positive sputum culture suggest the possibility of sepsis.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH is markedly elevated, and the patient may be at risk for further deterioration if not treated.
* Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement since admission, and there is a risk of further complications if not treated.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and there is a risk of further deterioration if not treated.
* Pericardial effusion: The patient has a small pericardial effusion, and there is a risk of further complications if not treated.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia
* Levothyroxine IV for hypothyroidism
* Sedation weaning
* Ventilator weaning
* Increase in bowel regimen
* Restarted on home topiramate, divalproex
* Holding home clonazepam and zolpidem
* Monitoring for sepsis and respiratory failure
* Monitoring for hypothyroidism and pericardial effusion

CT Head:
   No acute intracranial process. No hemorrhage. MRI is more sensitive for
   stroke.
   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Likely CAP v. aspiration; less likely HAP.  Urine legionella Ag neg.
   Favor broad antibiotic coverage at this time pending further micro and
   clinical history data.  Partial re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent
   left mid-lung infiltrate. Increase in leukocytosis.
   - Cont vanc, zosyn, levofloxacin for broad empiric coverage
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily RSBI/SBT
   - Wean sedation as tolerated
   Leukocytosis: Increased today. Currently treating pneumonia with broad
   abx. U/A on admit inconclusive for infection. Not on steroids.
   - Add differential
   - Recheck U/A with Ucx; check C. diff
   - Cont above abx
   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of
   infection; may have contribution from propofol used for sedation. Did
   not require pressors. Currently stable on maintenance fluids with
   improved UOP.
   - consider switching to fentanyl/versed if persistent hypotension
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Elevated at 15. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
   and benzos. [**Month (only) 11**] have ketosis from poor po intake.
   - Check lactate with next ABG
   - Recheck U/A
   - Cont maintenance fluids and tube feeds
   Pericardial effusion: Small without evidence of tamponade on TTE.
   Thyroid disorder: Per OSH report, may have hypothyroidism; rx for
   armourthyroid last filled in [**12-12**]. Unclear if pt taking medications for
   this. TSH markedly elevated.
   - Check free T4
   - start levothyroxine IV
   Constipation: No BM since admit
   - increase bowel regimen
   Increased lethargy/altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH.
   Given positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone also
   concerning for overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related
   to known bipolar disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known
   seizure disorder.
   - likely hypothyroidism contributing
   - Reassess neuro status as wean sedation
   - Restarted on home topiramate, divalproex,
   - Hold seroquel for now
   - Holding home clonazepam while on sedation
   - Holding home zolpidem
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2167-6-9**] 11:59 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM

   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and a recent presentation to the emergency department with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia, likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient has several potential medical complications that need to be monitored and addressed:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's left lung is collapsed, and she has a history of respiratory failure requiring intubation. Monitoring of respiratory status, including frequent arterial blood gas analysis and serial chest X-rays, is essential to ensure that the patient's lung function improves.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a moderate growth of Staphylococcus aureus in her sputum, which is a potential source of sepsis. Monitoring of her temperature, white blood cell count, and other laboratory values is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, and her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is markedly elevated. Treatment with levothyroxine is necessary to stabilize her thyroid function.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade on echocardiogram. Monitoring of her cardiac function and echocardiogram is necessary to detect any changes in her pericardial effusion.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may be a sign of infection or inflammation. Monitoring of her white blood cell count and other laboratory values is necessary to detect any signs of infection or inflammation.
6. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which may be related to sepsis, hypothyroidism, or other underlying medical conditions. Monitoring of her blood pressure and cardiac function is necessary to detect any changes in her blood pressure.
7. Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement since admission and may be at risk for constipation. Monitoring of her bowel movements and treatment with laxatives or stool softeners may be necessary.
8. Altered mental status: The patient has a history of bipolar disorder and may be at risk for altered mental status. Monitoring of her mental status and treatment with mood stabilizers or other medications may be necessary.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including respiratory failure, pneumonia, hypothyroidism, pericardial effusion, leukocytosis, hypotension, constipation, and altered mental status. Monitoring of her respiratory, cardiac, and neurological status is necessary to detect any changes in her condition and to provide appropriate treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder and hypothyroidism who presented to the hospital with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was intubated and found to have left lung collapse, likely secondary to mucous plugging from extensive consolidative pneumonia. She has been treated with broad antibiotic coverage and is being weaned off sedation and respiratory support. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and anion gap, as well as low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) levels. She has also been diagnosed with pericardial effusion and is being treated with levothyroxine IV.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and anion gap suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's left lung collapse and pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
3. Thyroid storm: The patient's TSH level of 54 and free T4 level of <0.10 suggest hypothyroidism, which can lead to thyroid storm if left untreated.
4. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's pericardial effusion may lead to cardiac tamponade, which can cause cardiac arrest and death.
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and pericardial effusion may lead to infection, which can spread to other parts of the body and cause organ failure.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's constipation and lack of bowel movement may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and lethargy may be related to hypothyroidism, overdose, or medication effect, and may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or coma.
8. DVT: The patient's immobility and history of hypothyroidism may increase her risk of developing DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad antibiotic coverage for pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
3. Continue to wean the patient off sedation and respiratory support as tolerated.
4. Monitor the patient's thyroid function closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider echocardiogram to evaluate pericardial effusion.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and consider increasing bowel regimen if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider restarting home medications for bipolar disorder if necessary.
8. Consider prophylactic anticoagulation to prevent DVT.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple medical conditions. The patient's chief complaint is not specified, but the note suggests that the patient is experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), or aspiration with mucous plugging.

The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with pressure support ventilation (PSV) and has been stable. However, the patient's mental status is somewhat precluding extubation, and the plan is to continue sedation and assess for possible extubation later today or tomorrow.

The patient has a history of overdose and profound hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to the obtundation. The patient is receiving IV levothyroxine and has been restarted on mood stabilizers.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 23.5 K/uL. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and the plan is to add on differential and evaluate the results. The patient's lactate level is elevated, and the plan is to continue fluid resuscitation targeted to urine output and blood pressure.

The patient has a pericardial effusion noted on the CT scan, but there is no evidence of tamponade on examination. The patient's coagulation studies show a prolonged PT and PTT, and the plan is to continue heparin prophylaxis.

The patient's medication list includes various antibiotics, anticoagulants, and sedatives, which may be contributing to the obtundation. The patient's fluid balance is slightly negative, with a total fluid input of 2,339 mL and a total fluid output of 2,705 mL.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if the patient's mental status does not improve and the patient is not extubated.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and leukocytosis suggest that the patient may be at risk for sepsis. If the patient's condition worsens, the patient may require more aggressive management, including vasopressors and renal replacement therapy.
3. Pericardial tamponade: Although the patient's CT scan does not show evidence of tamponade, the patient's pericardial effusion may worsen if the patient's condition does not improve.
4. Bleeding: The patient's prolonged PT and PTT may increase the risk of bleeding, especially if the patient requires invasive procedures or has a traumatic injury.
5. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated lactate level suggest that the patient may have an underlying infection. If the patient's condition worsens, the patient may require more aggressive management, including broad-spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical conditions, including hypoxemic respiratory failure, leukocytosis, and pericardial effusion. The patient requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch, 59.1 kg individual with respiratory failure due to LLL pneumonia. They are receiving IV levothyroxine for possible myxedema and have a history of overdose, polypharmacy, and profound hypothyroidism. The patient is mechanically ventilated with a CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 40%, and PEEP 5 cmH2O. They have a diminished breath sound on the left lateral side, and their peripheral vascular pulses are not assessed.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 11.3-23.5 K/uL
* Hct: 31.7-30.5%
* Plt: 73 K/uL
* Cr: 0.7-0.8 mg/dL
* TCO2: 26-27 mmHg
* Glucose: 122-91 mg/dL
* Albumin: 3.2 g/dL
* Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.2 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* TSH: 54

Imaging studies show:

* CXR: Unchanged, ETT 5.1 cm above carina, LUL and LLL atelectasis
* CT head: Negative for acute process
* Sputum: MSSA and GPCs

Assessment and Plan:

The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to CAP, HAP, or aspiration with mucous plugging. They are stable on PSV and will continue to be monitored for possible extubation. Broad antibiotic coverage is being provided, and the plan is to narrow to just Zosyn once CX data is available.

The patient also has possible sepsis, hypotension with elevated lactate overnight, and fluid responsive. They will be closely monitored for signs of infection and will have their fluid resuscitation targeted to UOP and BP.

Additionally, the patient has leukocytosis, and a low threshold will be used to rescan their chest for empyema. They have a pericardial effusion noted on CT scan, but no evidence of pulsus on exam. They will have a TTE without tamponade evidence.

The patient's obtundation is attributed to polypharmacy, history of overdose, and profound hypothyroidism. They will receive IV levothyroxine and will have their mood stabilizers resumed. Sedatives will be held, and the remainder of the plan will be followed per housestaff note.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if they do not respond to treatment or if they develop further complications such as pneumonia or atelectasis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and elevated lactate levels suggest possible sepsis. If left untreated, sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection or inflammation. If left untreated, leukocytosis can lead to organ dysfunction and increased risk of infection.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may worsen if left untreated, leading to cardiac tamponade and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Myxedema: The patient's profound hypothyroidism may worsen if left untreated, leading to further complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cognitive impairment.
6. Overdose: The patient's history of overdose may increase their risk of overdose-related complications, such as respiratory depression, cardiac arrest, and death.
7. Polypharmacy: The patient's polypharmacy may increase their risk of adverse drug reactions, interactions, and complications.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's tube feeds being held may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which can worsen their overall health and increase their risk of complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia with MSSA+ sputum cx. No obstructive
   lesion on bronch. Partial re-expansion s/p bronch x 2 with persistent
   left mid-lung infiltrate.
   - continue zosyn
   - d/c levofloxacin and vancomycin
   - f/u pending cx cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily wake-up and SBT
   - will re bronch today to assess airway
   Leukocytosis: Pt febrile overnight although WBC now improving.
   Currently treating pneumonia with concern for complicated PNA or
   parapneumonic effusion. Repeat U/A unremarkable; Ucx pending. Not on
   steroids. Ddx includes seizure.
   - Cont to trend WBC and temp curve
   - Abx as above pending sputum, blood, and urine cx data
   - Consider EEG
   Altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH with limited
   response off sedation. CT head negative. Likely hypothyroidism
   contributing with possibility of myxedema coma; h/o poor control. Given
   positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone, concern for
   overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related to known bipolar
   disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known seizure disorder.
   - Appreciate endo recs; given loading dose of levothyroxine 300mcg and
   to cont on 75mcg daily
   - Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel, clonazepam, and
   zolpidem for now
   - Consider EEG
   - Reassess neuro status daily off propofol
   Hypothyroidism: Poorly controlled with widely fluctuating TSH on review
   of past med records.
   - Cont levothyroxine 75mcg
   - F/u cortisol level to assess adrenal axis
   - F/u endo recs
   Bipolar disorder: Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel
   and clonazepam for now
   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of
   infection but MAPs stably above goal off pressors with likely
   contribution from used for sedation.
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Stable at 13 today. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
